CLM SMALL BUSINESS
SE Business/Financial Desk; SECTC
HD They May Be Mundane, but Low-Tech Businesses Are Booming
BY By ELIZABETH OLSON
WC 1546 words
PD 28 April 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 6
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Forget Web sites and molecular imaging. The biggest fields of opportunity for aspiring entrepreneurs are the same mundane ventures that have been kicking around for decades.

Think landscaping companies, child-care providers, janitorial services and nail and hair salons. In a generally buoyant market for low-technology businesses, those are four of the biggest winners by far. Altogether, sole proprietorships in the United States, a rough measure of the size of the small-business low-technology sector, grew by nearly 4 percent in 2002, the latest year with statistics available, to 17.6 million, and their combined revenue increased by 5.5 percent, to $770 billion. The figures come from the Census Bureau's Economic Census, a snapshot of the American economy that is taken every five years.

TD 

And the trends that drove the increases in low-tech businesses have only accelerated, the bureau's economists say, as the nation's economy has rebounded and employment has recovered.

Growth in housing has increased demand for lawn care, the office construction boom has created a need for cleaning crews, more families than ever have two working spouses and need child care, and more women are treating themselves to trips to the beauty parlor, the economists say.

That reflects a truth about American entrepreneurship that is often lost in the breathless news coverage of the latest Silicon Valley start-up or biotechnology wonder: most of the growth involves tried-and-true undertakings that are unlikely to yield overnight riches but are open to anyone with tenacity and grit.

Landscaping experienced the most growth in the Census Bureau's survey.

The number of sole proprietorships that create and care for people's gardens and lawns surged by 21.5 percent in 2002, to 210,000, and their combined revenue increased by 11.6 percent, to $4.8 billion.

Hilary Finn, who runs HomeGrown, a landscaping company in Brooklyn, helps explain the profession's popularity. Ms. Finn, 46, spent a decade as a personal trainer, but after giving birth to a second daughter in 2002, decided to switch occupations, for the flexible hours and the chance to express her artistic impulses.

''Since I was a child, I had been creating gardens,'' she said. ''I had graduated having studied painting and sculpture, but not design, at Empire State College. But I loved spaces and moving things around and creating spaces outside.''

Ms. Finn enrolled in the New York Botanical Garden design program in the Bronx, and started constructing gardens in containers and window boxes. ''Then I realized that Brooklyn backyards are like a container,'' she said, and she began to work with a fellow designer to design plots that are often no bigger than 25 feet by 50 feet. Demand for her work spread quickly by word of mouth. ''My business has doubled every year,'' she said, although she noted that her revenue is not yet a living.

Paula Turpin, a former school bus driver, took a different route, borrowing a few thousand dollars from the federal government to launch her hair salon, Truly Blessed Styles, in the Long Island town of Shirley, N.Y., five years ago, primarily because she wanted to run her own show.

She joined a thriving trade. The number of hair salons with the same person as owner and stylist grew 5.6 percent in 2002, the Census Bureau says, and the total number of establishments, including ones with paid staff, surpassed 400,000, with $8.4 billion in annual revenue.

Nail salons, which cater to the same clientele, grew even faster, up 8.7 percent to nearly 90,000, with annual revenue of $1.9 billion, the bureau says.

Ms. Turpin, drawing on her experience at other hair salons, set up hers in a strip shopping center in April 2000. She styles, cuts and colors hair for her clients by herself. Ms. Turpin's retired mother helps her schedule appointments and keep the books. Her daughter, a college student, pitches in when she can to braid clients' hair.

''Now I have my own business, and I'm able to have flexibility,'' said Ms. Turpin, 36. ''And I definitely have plans to expand. I want to add a barber shop in the back, and a place to sell beauty supplies in the front of the store.''

Ms. Finn and Ms. Turpin share two distinguishing characteristics of single-owner businesses: pride of ownership and desire to take control of their lives, said Erin Fuller, executive director of the National Association of Women Business Owners.

''Often, these owners do not want their business to become super large,'' she said. ''They take pride in their craft and, by keeping small, they can control that.''

Ann Bolf, 36, is a good example of that. After divorcing her husband, she opened a hair salon in her home in Stow, Ohio, in September 2002. She sends her three children, 19, 16 and 12, off to school each morning and then cooks their dinner before her first appointment each day. That way, she can easily put the evening meal on the table.

And she has fun in between. ''When it's one chair, one stylist and one client, the relationship takes a different turn,'' she said. ''It's a lot more personal, you can experiment more and I like it much better.'' Most important, Ms. Bolf says she can set her own hours and go on a school field trip or take care of a sick child whenever the need arises.

A continuing increase in the number of women in the workplace has helped spur a 5.9 percent rise in the number of child-care providers in 2002, to 619,000 with revenues of more than $7 billion. Many were run in the owner's home.

Cleaning companies are in great demand, too. The number of janitorial services without paid employees soared by 20.4 percent in 2002, to 427,600, with almost $6 billion in revenue, the bureau says. One reason, according to a bureau analyst, was the decline in payroll jobs during the 2001 recession, which encouraged or forced many laid-off workers to branch out on their own. The same dynamic was at work in the explosion of landscaping businesses, he said.

Greg Littlefield started a lot earlier than that, abandoning his job in office equipment sales and management in 1990 to set up a cleaning company in Montgomery, Ala. But his reason for choosing that career is still valid today: it will never lack customers.

''I knew that I did not want to start a high-tech business,'' he said, ''because I had seen several companies built upon a certain technology go out of business overnight when a new technology emerged.''

His experience is proof that lack of expertise is no barrier to success. ''The early days were rough,'' said Mr. Littlefield, because he had no clue how to clean.

So he sold copiers part time and worked at a small moving company, learning the janitorial business by cleaning buildings at night. His company, Professional Facilities Management, eventually grew into a $15 million-a-year business, taking advantage of an increasing number of office buildings that needed cleaning. Mr. Littlefield is also president of the cleaning industry's association, the Building Service Contractors Association International,

The industry has been helped by schools, hospitals and government agencies that traditionally had in-house janitorial staffs but are now using contractors for the work, said Marketdata Enterprises, a independent research firm based in Tampa, Fla., that studies service industries.

The commercial cleaning industry rolled unscathed through the 2001 recession, according to Marketdata, with revenue growing 5.5 percent in 2002 and 5.9 percent in 2003, to $94.5 billion. John LaRosa, a spokesman for Marketdata, said his firm estimated that growth last year was 6.3 percent and that total receipts could exceed $128 billion by 2008.

''This is a low-tech business that's easy to enter, and many do,'' he said, with some entrepreneurs finding lucrative niches like damage restoration, mold remediation or maid services.

That was Mr. Littlefield's experience. He figured that to thrive in an industry where two out of three firms lose their contracts within a few years, his company had to become what he called a total facilities service provider. So he began developing a package of services, including housekeeping, landscaping, labor, minor maintenance and security services.

That meant eventually expanding to 900 employees, a far cry from the single-employee businesses that are proliferating now. But Mr. Littlefield said that he stayed true to his initial goal of maintaining control and flexibility by paring clients when they were not working out, providing extensive staff training and adopting company policies that were family-friendly.

Photos: Ann Bolf, owner of Ann's Artistry hair salon in Stow, Ohio, likes working for herself and arranging her work hours to suit her family's needs. (Photo by David Maxwell for The New York Times); Hilary Finn of Brooklyn quit a job as a personal trainer and enrolled in garden design courses that led her to open her landscaping business. (Photo by Angel Franco/The New York Times)

SE Business/Financial Desk; SECTC
HD Japan Corporate Survey Finds Optimism Is Up
BY By TODD ZAUN
WC 391 words
PD 2 July 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 4
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

TOKYO, July 1 -- Japanese corporate leaders were more optimistic about their prospects in June than they were three months earlier despite signs of a slowdown in exports, according to a quarterly business survey by the Bank of Japan.

The unexpectedly upbeat result of the central bank's closely watched Tankan survey of about 10,000 companies suggests that the economy continues to recover from a shallow recession last year as domestic demand grows.

TD 

Confidence improved in most categories of businesses, though large companies remained significantly more upbeat than small ones.

The benchmark index of large manufacturers, which includes about 1,200 of Japan's biggest companies, rose to 18 in June, from 14 in March. The index is calculated by subtracting the percentage of companies that say conditions are unfavorable from those that say they are favorable. A positive score means the optimists outnumber the pessimists.

Economists said one of the most encouraging parts of the report was a strong improvement in confidence among service companies, like banks and department stores. Confidence among large service companies rose to 15 in June, the highest level since 1992, from 11 in March.

The fact that a wide range of companies are becoming more optimistic even as exports remain relatively weak shows that businesses think that consumption may be strengthening after years of stagnation.

For much of the last decade, growth in the Japanese economy has been driven primarily by exports. Though robust export growth has generated a series of relatively strong recoveries in recent years, each has been short-lived because demand at home has lagged.

But in the last year, the economy has shown new signs of life. Banks have cleaned up the bad loans that once saddled their industry, and many big companies are hiring again.

''The economy is coming back onto a normal footing,'' said Stefan Worrall, an economist in Tokyo for Credit Suisse First Boston Securities. ''This is obviously feeding into the confidence we are seeing. Sentiment among manufacturers has been surprisingly resilient.''

Japan's unemployment rate remained at a six-year low of 4.4 percent in May, unchanged from April, according to a separate government report. Another report released Friday showed vehicle sales rose 8.6 percent in June from a year earlier.

CLM HOUSE PROUD
SE House & Home/Style Desk; SECTF
HD Polished Primitives In the Dunes
BY By RAUL A. BARRENECHE
WC 1151 words
PD 8 September 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 11
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Amagansett, N.Y. -- CHARLES MILITE'S weekend home, nestled behind the dunes in the Napeague area here, went from empty shell to furnished house in a single day.

On a steamy morning in late June, as the 3,000-square-foot house was nearing completion, a tractor trailer pulled into Mr. Milite's driveway and deposited a 20-foot shipping container sent from Indonesia. It contained an entire houseful of furnishings, unloaded by a crew of 10, that Mr. Milite (pronounced mih-LIT-ee) had ordered eight weeks earlier from Andrianna Shamaris, the owner of stores in Malibu, Calif., and SoHo in Manhattan.

TD 

Ms. Shamaris, who lived in Indonesia for more than a year after leaving London, her childhood home, imports furniture and clothing -- including items of her own design -- from Bali, Sumatra and Madura. With warm natural materials, clean lines and simple silhouettes, her furniture is at once modern and exotic, primitive and sophisticated -- more Christian Liaigre than Pier 1.

She helped pack more than 90 items (70 of them pieces of furniture) into the container bound for Mr. Milite's home while on one of her periodic buying expeditions in Indonesia in May. The contents included recycled teak slab and rattan sofas, a bed made of salvaged timbers, hand-carved sculptures of tamarind wood, raffia pillows, chopsticks and lacquered palm wood bowls.

Mr. Milite hired Ms. Shamaris after visiting her SoHo store, and after seeing the interiors of a sprawling beachfront home, just down the street, that she had furnished for his friend Danny Errico, a founder of the Equinox gym chain and now a partner in James Hotels.

Ms. Shamaris does not consider herself an interior designer, and she did not charge Mr. Milite a design fee above the price of the furnishings, which cost $35,000, plus $5,000 for shipping. (Ms. Shamaris said she gave Mr. Milite, a former model and well-connected restaurateur, a $30,000 discount in the hope that her work for him will lead to other clients.) She said she is generally able to offer goods below normal retail prices because she acts as designer, manufacturer and retailer, and because she works directly with artisans throughout Indonesia.

Mr. Milite said he felt from the outset that the sand dunes and coastal pines around his house called for simple interior materials. ''We're surrounded by a nature reserve, so I said we needed natural woods and fabrics. The house has a lot of wood, very little Sheetrock,'' said Mr. Milite. ''I didn't want a faux Balinese house. I wanted it to feel like a beach house on Long Island.''

In April, Ms. Shamaris visited Mr. Milite's house, a clean-lined, contemporary take on the classic Hamptons shingle style designed by James D'Auria, an architect with offices in Manhattan and Amagansett. Inside, the house is modern and loft-like, a minimalist-goes-craftsman style with a sloped ceiling that peaks at 25 feet in the living room, cedar paneled walls, a polished concrete tile fireplace surround and a hearth open to both a sitting area and the kitchen.

Ms. Shamaris concluded that the lofty ceilings and bright rooms called for a few large furnishings, ''not lots of little things all over the place,'' she said, referring to the tendency to fill beach homes with nautical keepsakes.

''The scale, shapes and materials are complementary to the house,'' said Mr. D'Auria.

Since many of the furnishings Ms. Shamaris designed for the house were custom-made in Indonesia, Mr. Milite, a self-confessed ''control freak'' who normally spends years looking for the right couch, didn't know exactly what they would look like until the container arrived.

''It was really nerve-racking. I had no idea what was going to come out of the truck,'' said Mr. Milite, 46, an owner of three restaurants, including the Coffee Shop on Union Square. ''It was like a blind date, but with furniture that I was stuck with.''

Ms. Shamaris kept her cool. ''He stood there and said, 'This better be good,''' said Ms. Shamaris, 39, as she reclined last month on a teak chaise by Mr. Milite's pool in low-cut jeans and a crocheted bikini top. ''I said, 'Darling, just chill.'''

Mr. Milite had the assurance that Ms. Shamaris's clients include George Clooney, Daryl Hannah and Katie Ford. ''A lot of her pieces combine an Asian feeling with a clean modern look,'' said Ms. Ford, the chief executive of Ford Models, who bought a pair of bamboo tables and an antique Indonesian throw for her SoHo loft from Ms. Shamaris. ''They have a warm ethnic or indigenous feeling, but they're not hippie looking.''

Naturally, the pool deck is the hub of summer entertaining. Ms. Shamaris obliged by ringing the pool, where Mr. Milite hosts informal parties, with rattan floor pillows she designed and a teak platform bed for three that she had fabricated in Jepara, in Central Java. As cooler weather arrives, the focus will shift to the eat-in kitchen, which Ms. Shamaris furnished with a hefty table made of joined slabs of raw teak wood with curved edges. Ms. Shamaris left the tabletop completely natural: no shellac or stain. For a contemporary counterpoint to the table's organic curves, she designed straight-backed dining chairs in white resin, with slices of bamboo embedded in the resin.

Ms. Shamaris said she wanted to design ''something primitive but really sexy'' for the second-floor master bedroom. So she created an oversized platform bed framed in well-worn beams and floor joists salvaged from old houses on Madura, an island off the northeast coast of Java. Ms. Shamaris gave them a shiny patina by rubbing the lip of a Coca-Cola bottle over the wood. ''It makes the wood look like glass,'' she said.

Ms. Shamaris estimated that each of the bed's roughly eight-foot-long by eight-inch-wide slabs of ironwood, a dense hardwood, weighed about 200 pounds.

''This furniture is pretty much indestructible, unless you take a hacksaw to it,'' said Mr. Milite. ''That's what you want at the beach, to be able to lock the door when you leave and not worry about precious things.''

Photos: BALI MODERN -- The living area, above left, has flooring of pickled old-growth heart pine, a teak sofa ($14,000) and a coffee table ($4,900) made with a section of teak root. The fireplace, above right, is faced with concrete tiles and edged with industrial steel.; EAST FORK ETHNIC -- Charles Milite furnished his weekend house, above, with pieces by Andrianna Shamaris, seated in her mahogany rocker ($980 at Andrianna Shamaris stores), top right. Below, the pool has a teak lounging platform for three. (Photographs by Laurie Lambrecht for The New York Times)

CLM PRACTICAL MATTERS
SE Small Business; SECTG
HD Tips for Managing The Nuts and Bolts Like the Big Guys
BY By ERIC DASH
WC 747 words
PD 20 September 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 2
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

SMALL-BUSINESS owners must often juggle the same complex accounting, legal and management issues that large corporations do without nearly the same resources or staff. ''There are so many factors involved, and the interplay between the personal and business complicates things even further,'' said James A. Seidel, an executive at RIA, which provides small-business advice. While there is no substitute for hands-on experience, here are some tips that can help out small companies:

TD 

Take advantage of free online services to register your company and establish an employer taxpayer code. Today, several government sites are making the registration process paperless, fast, easy and free. Many states have Internet sites where entrepreneurs can check off whether a new company will be a sole proprietorship S-corporation or C-corporation; each has legal and tax pros and cons. The Internal Revenue Service has forms online for establishing an employer identification code, required for opening a corporate bank account and filing taxes. Of course, forming a company is more than filing a document. Most small-business experts recommend consulting a lawyer first. ''If you set up the wrong type of entity, you may be hamstringing yourself and you may have to start over,'' Mr. Seidel said.

Set up a board of advisers. For small-business owners, a large Rolodex of industry contacts can be critical for success. But how does one develop such a network? Eva Rosenberg, publisher of TaxMama.com, suggests that entrepreneurs establish an advisory board that includes a handful of industry experts, local business leaders, an important supplier and customers, as well as the company's outside lawyer and accountant. The members, she said, should be paid a small retainer for their work and meet formally once a year to discuss big-picture plans. A side benefit may be access to their contacts, not to mention specific advice.

Credit-card transaction fees may be more negotiable than you think. Credit-card companies tend to group small merchants in categories, like restaurants or retail stores, that are all charged certain transaction fees. But if you can make a case that you deserve better, it may be possible to lower those rates. Small-business consultants advise talking to trade association and other industry contacts to find out what similar companies pay, then approaching the credit-card companies. ''A lot of times they will negotiate, and if they won't, go back every six months and try,'' said Stephen Spinelli Jr., an entrepreneurship professor at Babson College who advises small and medium-size companies.

Keep your eye on the cash. For small businesses, cash flow is king. But the reality is that most owners are not good at managing it. ''They either work on a low cash balance, or if things go well, they may use their company as their own personal bank,'' Mr. Spinelli said. For businesses with a steady stream of revenue, Mr. Spinelli recommends having at least enough cash to cover one purchasing cycle. Then if a key customer has to cut back on orders, he said, or another unexpected disruption occurs, there is time to recover. For fast-growing companies, planning is crucial. Explaining your business strategy to vendors and suppliers may be the best way to prevent a cash shortage early if you expect to be flush with money later. ''What happens, usually, is they make the call at the time of need rather than doing the planning in advance of the need,'' Mr. Spinelli said.

Hand off a headache. Managing the monthly payroll can be as big a headache for a 14-person company as it is for a corporation with 14,000 employees. There are literally thousands of different tax regulations that make it difficult for the small-business owner to navigate. That is why Mr. Spinelli says it is more efficient and cost-effective to hire a company, like Paychex, for the task. For about $150 an employee, a payroll service company handles everything from entering tax deduction and bonus information to cutting the checks. ''What most small-business folks do is try to do it in house because they don't want to pay that bill,'' Mr. Spinelli said. ''But they usually parcel them out to someone in the organization. But if they're not skilled, they can get in trouble by filing improperly or late.''

Drawings (Illustrations by Felix Sockwell)

CLM LOOKING AHEAD
SE Small Business; SECTG
HD Putting Retirement Eggs in More Than the 401(k) Basket
BY By FRAN HAWTHORNE
WC 1417 words
PD 20 September 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 9
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

CONVENTIONAL wisdom asserts that most small companies cannot afford to offer retirement plans. If they do -- so the conventional wisdom goes -- it will be the most bare-bones 401(k), with the employee contributing all the money.

Data from the independent Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington seems to support these assumptions: while only 16.3 percent of people working for a company with fewer than 10 employees had access to a retirement plan in 2003 (the most recent figures available), the numbers rose in lockstep with company size, reaching 72.6 percent of workers at companies with at least 1,000 employees.

TD 

Nevertheless, the money management industry has created a variety of relatively low-cost retirement plans tailored to small companies, even those with just one or two employees. And more businesses are signing on.

For instance, more than 367,000 businesses with fewer than 100 employees now offer 401(k) plans, up from about 169,000 a decade ago and 260,000 in 1998, according to the consulting firm Cerulli Associates.

''The competitive pressures in the marketplace are the biggest impetus'' for business owners, said Charles Ledbetter, a senior vice president of the giant insurance brokerage Marsh Inc. and a specialist on retirement plans. ''It's probably the third-most important thing people ask in a job interview,'' after salary and health insurance.

The 2001 federal tax law gave the trend a push by introducing several incentives for small-business retirement plans. Probably most important were tax breaks that let owners and top managers put substantially more money into their own accounts than the rank and file can -- a disparity not usually allowed in these programs. Moreover, the administrative costs can often be kept to a few hundred dollars a year.

Many of the plans may seem similar. They generally work like a 401(k), with the employee getting an individual account, making the investment decisions and bearing the risk. Savings are almost always tax-deferred. But each plan has special features that might appeal to different types and sizes of small companies:

(Most contribution limits are indexed annually for inflation, so the figures in this article pertain to 2005. For workers age 50 and over, the limits are usually a little higher.)

SIMPLE I.R.A.

This is essentially a streamlined 401(k), limited by law to companies with a work force of 100 or less.

Employees may put in their own money, up to $10,000 a year, while the employer must contribute in one of two ways: matching employees' contributions up to 3 percent of their pay (to a maximum of $10,000), or paying a flat 2 percent of the salary of all eligible employees (to a maximum $4,200 a person), regardless of whether they contributed. Virtually all employees become part of the plan from the day they are hired. Thanks to minimal government paperwork, administering the plans runs just $10 to $50 an employee a year, experts say.

The big disadvantage is that simplicity can mean inflexibility. In a Simple I.R.A., the employer's contribution is the same percentage for everyone, even employees who stay only six months. For the larger small businesses, that can add up.

Another problem is the relatively low contribution limit. ''If you've got a business owner who may be 45 or 50 and he's spent all his time and assets to get the business going, now he needs to put away $20,000 a year for retirement,'' said Michael J. Patton, a financial planner with J.P. Morgan Chase. ''The Simple plan won't allow him to put that much in.''

For all those reasons, Mr. Patton and others say that Simple plans generally appeal to companies with a staff of 10 to 15 and low turnover. ''This is more of an employee benefit, not a tax break for the owner,'' said Joanne Voelcker, the principal in charge of small-business services at the Vanguard Group. Using the guaranteed employer funding as a lure, ''it would be good for an industry where you're competing for employees.''

SIMPLIFIED EMPLOYEE PENSION

The simplified employee pension, known as SEP, is another pared-down plan aimed at the smallest companies, but with a starkly different approach than a Simple I.R.A. It is so flexible that employers can contribute zero to 25 percent of each employee's pay to a maximum of $42,000.

Moreover, the percentage can change each year, as long as it's the same for all employees. ''If you don't have a profit, you don't have to contribute,'' Mr. Patton said. Employees, meanwhile, put in nothing.

A second advantage is that the high maximum gives the business owner a big tax shelter. And there is little paperwork to file with the federal government.

But these plans share a disadvantage with Simple I.R.A.'s: virtually all workers must be covered equally from Day 1. Accordingly, experts recommend the plans for professional companies, like doctors' offices, with small staffs and low turnover. They are also good for companies with volatile earnings.

401(k)

The 401(k) is the giant of the retirement world, accounting for about 41 percent of the $4.9 trillion in all company-sponsored retirement assets, Vanguard says. It allows every gimmick and frill a manager could want. For instance, matching contributions by the company are voluntary, and employees can be required to wait as long as a year before becoming eligible, which solves the high-turnover problem. But with a huge amount of government paperwork and administrative costs of typically a few thousand dollars a year, small businesses have difficulty affording a 401(k).

But there are some variations meant for small companies, especially for owners who want to amass a large nest egg.

The ''individual,'' or ''solo,'' 401(k) is specifically for companies in which the only employees are the owner and spouse. There is also a ''safe harbor'' 401(k), in which companies must contribute to all employee accounts. In return, this is one of the times when the 2001 law lets higher-income managers put in a bigger percentage of their compensation than lower earners can.

On Jan. 1, a new plan, the Roth 401(k), will be available. Contributions are taxable going in but tax-deferred when withdrawn after age 59 1/2 -- similar to a Roth I.R.A. but the opposite of a standard 401(k).

PROFIT SHARING

A profit-sharing plan has the flexibility of the simplified employee pension, in that companies can change their contributions year to year. And like the 401(k), it allows a waiting period before employees are eligible. The biggest disadvantage is that the company has to file the same complex paperwork as with a 401(k).

While a profit-sharing plan can be a business's sole retirement vehicle, many managers tack one of these on top of a 401(k) to increase their match in good times. There are also variations, like ''age-weighted'' profit-sharing plans that allow bigger percentages for older workers -- which often means the owners and top managers -- on the theory that they have less time to build up their savings. Generally, these plans may be good for start-ups with unpredictable cash flow or high turnover.

DEFINED BENEFIT

If any kind of retirement plan would seem impossible for a small company, it is the traditional pension, or defined benefit, plan, in which the company sends checks to every retiree, bearing all the responsibility of financing and investment risk. Yet plenty of small companies are embracing these programs, particularly those with fewer than 25 employees and owners who are nearing age 65.

''Often it's the only way an older key employee or owner can save fast enough for retirement,'' said Elise Pilkington, assistant director of marketing for retirement and investor services at Principal Financial Group in Des Moines. That's because the pension is based on age, years of service and salary, a formula that usually favors owners and top managers. When Principal hands out its annual awards for small companies with the best benefits, a substantial percentage of the winners usually have these plans. Any retirement program may be expensive for businesses to have, Mr. Patton of J.P. Morgan Chase said, but ''they can't afford not to.''

Drawing (Drawing by Ray Vella)

RE 
usa : United States | namz : North America

CLM AFTER KATRINA
SE Small Business; SECTG
HD The Forms Have Gone Out, but the Help Will Take Longer
BY By ELIZABETH OLSON
WC 1088 words
PD 20 September 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 8
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

HERE'S one way of measuring the need for disaster help: through last week, the Small Business Administration distributed 741,917 loan applications for those hurt by Hurricane Katrina.

Here's one way of measuring the recovery: as of last week, about 2,400 applications had been filed, and so far none have been approved for small businesses.

TD 

Even so, federal and state agencies, legislatures and private groups are putting in place a wide range of assistance for small businesses. But right now, the businesses themselves are assessing what they need.

Not only was a whole region devastated, but small businesses also suffered disproportionately because the Gulf Coast had a large number of companies with fewer than 50 employees, according to economy.com.

The first stop for small-business owners is the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which screens and refers callers to the Small Business Administration for emergency disaster loans.

A small business can qualify for up to $1.5 million under two different disaster recovery loan programs, said Carol Chastang, a spokeswoman for the agency. The Physical Disaster Business Loan provides loans, at 4 percent for up to 30 years, to help rebuild and replace lost items like office furniture and computers. The Economic Injury Disaster Loan offers loans, at the same rate, to allow companies to pay routine expenses, including payroll, rent and utilities.

Last week, President Bush said he wanted to set up a ''Gulf Opportunity Zone'' in Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama, which would encourage small businesses to stay and new companies to open by providing them with tax breaks and loans.

Both houses of Congress are planning to broaden financial aid offerings for small-business owners struggling after Katrina.

The Senate last week passed measures to allow deferred repayments for Small Business Administration disaster loans for one year, and to increase their size to $10 million from $1.5 million. The House is considering proposals to broaden the agency's authority to allow it to assume a business's pre-existing debt payments for up to 36 months.

Louisiana is also trying to help what may be as many as 100,000 small businesses affected by the hurricane. Last week, the Louisiana Economic Development Agency announced several programs to help businesses return to normal, including working with Alabama and Mississippi to develop an overall federal aid request modeled after small-business assistance in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist acts.

The Louisiana Association of Business and Industry set up a Small Business Disaster Relief Fund to finance ''gap funding'' to pay any small-business expenses that are not covered by insurance, said Daniel Juneau, the association's director. This is important because flood damage is not covered by routine insurance policies, he said.

The group, which has 5,000 small-business members in the state, said it had set up a Web site, AccessLouisiana.com, that matches businesses in need with those that have services to offer. National groups are lending a helping hand. The National Small Business Association, an advocacy group, is trying to raise $250,000 for expenses not covered by insurance, said Scott Hauge, the founder of Small Business California, a group affiliate. The United States Chamber of Commerce's Center for Corporate Citizenship provides a resource guide on its Web site, uschamber.com/ccc, to help businesses identify their needs and resources to fill them, said Stephen Jordan, the executive director. The center also has a job bank to seek and place workers; it collects money to help small businesses and is in the process of setting up a program to connect companies that want to ''adopt'' storm-affected businesses.

The National Federation of Independent Business has a guide to hurricane assistance on its Web site, nfib.com, and its state representatives are working to help members. Ron Aldridge, the state director for Mississippi, estimates that 20 percent of the federation's 5,000 members in the state were hit.

Another small-business matchmaker is the National Association of Women Business Owners, which has joined other women's business groups to set up a Web site, womenbizrelief.com.

In the hurricane region, the Small Business Administration has 14 disaster recovery centers in Louisiana, eight in Alabama, six in Texas and five in Mississippi and more than doubled its work force, to nearly 2,000 people, to help process disaster relief loans.

Many small-business owners cannot focus on filling out government paperwork when they have more immediate tasks at hand, like searching for missing employees. John Rowland, for instance, left behind his 20-year-old company, Southern Hospitality Catering, in New Orleans when he evacuated hours before the hurricane. ''Right now we're looking for the people we lost,'' he said, speaking from a cellphone at a relative's home in McLean, Va. ''And then we will definitely be looking for capital to get started again.''

Luckily for Mr. Rowland, his building, in the city's warehouse area, is still standing although it needs repairs and to clean up spoiled food. He had been preparing a welcoming party for new students at Tulane University, which was cancelled as Katrina bore down on New Orleans. But he will have access to his financial records, which are necessary to fill out the Small Business Administration loan form.

''Typically, completing these forms takes a while,'' Ms. Chastang said. After small-business owners assemble their financial records, connect with insurers to assess damage, check local banks for loans and fill out the federal loan forms, their situation must be assessed by an agency loan verifier who physically examines the business before the federal loan is approved.

The biggest need right now, said Michael A. Mitterknight, an air-conditioning contractor in Metairie, a suburb of New Orleans, ''is money to help us keep afloat for a while, and money that can be paid back over a period of time.''

Mr. Mitterknight, whose business suffered limited damage and is already back at work, said, ''As much as I hate to say it, and I never believed in give-away programs, but just give me what I need to keep going.''

Photo: AFTERMATH -- Though the floodwaters have receded in many neighborhoods of New Orleans, the ground is covered in muck and debris. These demolished cars near Canal Street were moved to the sidewalk to make way for the cleanup. (Photo by Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)


NS

RE 
usa : United States | uss : Southern U.S. | namz : North America

AN 
Document NYTF000020050920e19k0001y


SE Business/Financial Desk; SECTC
HD Finland Again Ranks First Among Global Competitors
BY By TOM WRIGHT
CR International Herald Tribune
WC 665 words
PD 29 September 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 8
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

GENEVA, Sept. 28 -- Nordic countries remain more competitive than those of any other region, while Japan and the major economies of Europe have become less so, the World Economic Forum said Wednesday in its annual study.

Finland once again ended up in first place in the World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Index, which ranks 117 countries, while four other Nordic countries made the top 10. The United States, the world's largest economy, again ended up in second place.

TD 

The study assigned scores to nations by looking at factors like government economic policy, the strength of local institutions and the degree to which technology has been used to bolster growth.

Japan fell to 12th place, from 9th; Britain slipped to 13th, from 11th; Germany dropped to 15th place, from 13th. Spain fell to 29th, from 23rd; and France fell to 30th, from 27th. Italy remained in 47th place, between Greece and Botswana.

''High labor market rigidities, and, in particular, the ease of hiring and firing, contribute to explaining why Europe lags behind U.S. performance,'' Beatrice Weder di Mauro, an economics professor at Mainz University, wrote in a paper for the forum. ''Improving the flexibility of labor markets should be high on Europe's reform agenda.'' Japan's rating fell because of ''the deterioration of its public finances,'' she wrote, though it the country more than compensated for it with its ''impressive technology performance.''

The Nordic countries, in contrast, drew praise.

Margareta Drzeniek, a senior economist at the World Economic Forum, said, ''The reasons for the strong performance by the Nordic countries is that they have very transparent systems, high levels of technology penetration, a well-educated work force and good macroeconomic management.''

African and Latin American nations filled most of the bottom spots, with Chad in last place. Two of Latin America's largest economies fell in the rankings: Mexico to 55th place, from 48th, and Brazil to 65th, from 57th. Chile, however, came in 23rd, outscoring some of the European Union economies on government transparency.

The performance of the Asian economies was mixed. Many of the so-called tiger economies in Asia ranked well, with Taiwan in fifth place and Singapore sixth. Tiger economy countries are nations that achieve high growth by pursuing an export-driven trade strategy.

One of the biggest gains came in South Korea, which jumped to 17th place, from 29th last year, in part because of high scores in technology. The World Economic Forum report said that rapid growth in China and India, which placed 49th and 50th, respectively, could be threatened in the long term by factors like poor education systems and low use of technology. These factors were ''likely to slow down their ascension to the top tier of the most competitive economies in the world.''

China dropped from 46th place, while India rose from 55th. China and India lagged in the index because of ''serious problems'' with corruption, bureaucracy and education, Ms. Drzeniek said.

The high rankings of Finland, Sweden, Denmark, Iceland and Norway highlighted the countries' ability to foster a climate in which business can flourish while they also run large social welfare systems. Their success can in part be explained by high taxes, which most citizens accept in exchange for free health care and education, affordable child care and generous unemployment benefits.

But the high taxes have not discouraged entrepreneurs. The World Economic Forum praised Finland, home to global companies like Nokia, as ''one of the most innovative business environments in the world.'' The forum also highlighted Finland's ability to run a budget surplus while many European countries face large deficits.

The United States remains at the cutting edge of technology, the report said, citing its ''pipeline of innovation second to none in the world.'' But a growing budget deficit and other macroeconomic concerns kept it out of the top spot, according to the report.


NS 
weconf : World Economic Forum | e1117 : Business Sentiment | e11 : Economic Performance/Indicators | ecat : Economic News | ocat : International Pol-Econ Organizations

RE 
switz : Switzerland | eurz : Europe | weurz : Western Europe

PUB 
New York Times Digital (Full Text)

AN 
Document NYTF000020050929e19t0008r


CLM HOME NETWORKS
SE Circuits; SECTG
HD Anticipating a Wireless Cacophony, Device Supports One-on-One Talk Among Appliances
BY By MATT RICHTEL
WC 1393 words
PD 5 October 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 2
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

PALO ALTO, Calif. -- SELINA LO wants to slap the microwave around and make it play well with others.

Ms. Lo, 46, is the chief executive of Ruckus Wireless, a Silicon Valley start-up that is developing technology to connect home appliances wirelessly, including computers, televisions, satellite or cable boxes, even stereos.

TD 

It is a prize sought by many entrepreneurs despite the obstacles involved in creating uniform standards to link a host of consumer electronics. The challenges include coordinating telecommunications companies, computer companies and appliance makers; creating a technology consumers can use easily; and developing a sound business model.

And then there's the microwave. It is one of the many everyday items that can cause changes in airwaves and thus disrupt fragile wireless transmissions between, say, the cable box and the television. Other sources of disruption are as simple as human movement or interference from a neighbor's wireless signals.

Enter Ms. Lo, a veteran entrepreneur with a whirlwind style (and occasionally salty vocabulary), whose company has developed a multipronged antenna that is the underlying technology in its new wireless router. The antenna monitors the airwaves and changes the path of a wireless stream of data to avoid potential sources of interruption.

''Our software can actually change the antenna orientation in a millisecond,'' she said. ''If the microwave turns on, we find a path that actually faces the other way.''

Ms. Lo is already enjoying a taste of success. Her company last month began shipping its products to PCCW, a telecommunications provider in Hong Kong that delivers television channels over high-speed Internet lines. Ms. Lo said PCCW intended to use the Ruckus technology to send an Internet signal wirelessly from the point where the cable or satellite line enters the home to a computer or television set-top box.

But there is a long way to go before wires are removed from the home entertainment experience, despite vocal assurances from the consumer electronics industry that the wireless home is right around the corner.

Julie Ask, research director at Jupiter Research, said that while momentum was building, the wireless home ''is not close.'' She added: ''There isn't somebody taking a lead in integrating the systems in the household.''

According to Jupiter's research, for example, only 2 percent of those who use Wi-Fi in their homes apply the technology to send video signals.

Michael Gartenberg, vice president and research director at Jupiter, said the few people using wireless technology to, for instance, allow their TV's to stream programming from their computers, were early adopters who did not mind spending quality time with the user manual.

''Dad has to be C.I.O., mom's running the help desk and the kids are doing tech support,'' he said.

Many entrepreneurs and major companies are working to resolve these technological and business issues. Frank Hanzlik, managing director of the Wi-Fi Alliance, a trade organization in Austin, Tex., representing 240 computer and electronics makers worldwide, said it would take three years before Wi-Fi was a mainstream technology used for a wireless entertainment system.

Industry analysts say it is too soon to tell whether Ms. Lo has what it takes to break out of the pack and become a leader. ''There are a lot of folks doing stuff,'' Mr. Gartenberg said, referring to the competing ways of unwiring a home. ''We're still in the nascent stages of this.''

Ms. Lo, who has been with Ruckus since May 2003, when it was called Video54, officially introduced Ruckus under its new name last month. One thing it has going for it is $14 million in venture capital financing, including $9 million that was committed last month.

One of the lead investors, Sequoia Capital in Menlo Park, Calif., invested in Ruckus because it thought the company's new antenna and its underlying software was a major competitive advantage, said Gaurav Garg, a partner at Sequoia.

The antenna looks a bit like a flat star fish with six prongs. It is unusual in that it constantly monitors the airwaves for disruptions, then changes the direction that a signal is being sent. If, for instance, the direct line between an Internet signal and the computer or television is suddenly disrupted, the antenna would find one of 62 other routes. If a direct path between two appliances is disrupted, the antenna might avoid the interference by picking a cleaner path (like bouncing the signal off the walls).

The prongs of the antenna don't actually change direction, and the antenna itself does not move. Instead, software inside the antenna selects the best path and uses the corresponding antenna prong to send the information. In fact, the software and the antenna are embedded in a wireless router that is attached to the point where a television or Internet connection enters the home. The antenna then distributes the signal wirelessly throughout the house.

The creators of the antenna, the engineers Bill Kish and Victor Shtrom, have been developing the technology with help from Sequoia since early 2003.

At the time, Ms. Lo was in her second semiretirement. One day, while waiting at home for the satellite technician to hook up a new television, she became frustrated about having to lay more wires throughout her house to connect all her gadgets.

''I thought, what if I want to move my TV? What if I want to move my furniture? Do I have to get the cable guy out again?'' she said. ''We are slaves to all the cabling and wiring.''

Ms. Lo quickly learned that there are steep challenges in technology and in business. She was brought into the company to confront both, particularly to find a way to make the technology profitable before all parts of a wireless home are in place.

Her solution is to take baby steps by creating partnerships with telecommunications companies. Similarly, she hopes to appeal to telecom giants in the United States like SBC Communications. Her sales pitch is that telecom providers, by using her wireless access points, can save money because they will not have to deploy technicians to drill holes and lay wires in consumers' homes.

Ms. Lo said the recommended price is $169 for the antenna, and $129 for the adapters that would allow appliances to receive the signals.

A first-generation immigrant who grew up in Hong Kong, Ms. Lo came to the United States to study at the University of California, Berkeley, where she graduated in 1982 with a degree in computer science.

She spent six years at Hewlett-Packard, working in software development and sales support, before deciding the company was too big for her. She thought the next company she worked for, Network Equipment Technologies in Fremont, Calif., was also too big, even though it had only 2,000 employees. In 1993, she decided to start her own company, co-founding Centillion, a maker of telecommunications equipment that was acquired two years later for $140 million by Bay Networks.

It was a big paycheck, and she promptly went about spending it on clothes, watches, jewelry, shoes and handbags. ''I like to make money,'' Ms. Lo said, ''and I like to spend it. I don't like the keeping-it part.'' She added with a laugh that the kinds of things she likes to buy ''are very cheap compared to the cars and planes guys like to collect.''

After a brief retirement, she was coaxed into taking a management job by the chief executive at Alteon Web Systems, which made technology to send high-speed data signals. She said she benefited to the tune of $20 million when the company was acquired by Nortel in 2000.

Ms. Lo has an intense but playful air, a person not easily offended. But she admits she herself can easily offend. She says, and her colleagues agree, that her direct style could be considered grating. ''I'm rough and I'm tough, and I sometimes really tick people off,'' she said.

Photos: LOOK, NO WIRES -- Selina Lo of Ruckus is focused on marketing the company's technology for connecting a TV, computer and home appliances. Its router senses interference and picks a clean path. (Photographs by Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)


IN 
i79022 : Wireless Telecommunications Services | i7902 : Telecommunications

NS

Document NYTF000020051005e1a50001m


CLM LIFE'S WORK
SE Job Market; SECT10
HD In-House Nepotism: Hiring the Husband
BY By Lisa Belkin
WC 853 words
PD 9 October 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 1
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

FIVE years ago, Teri Gault was working a collection of part-time jobs and raising two teenage boys in Santa Clarita, Calif. Her husband, Greg, earned most of the family's income working as a movie stuntman. Parsimonious by nature (her children often used other words for it), Ms. Gault had a favorite hobby -- she clipped coupons, managing to feed her family for only $37 a week. It was a skill that came in handy when work dried up suddenly for Mr. Gault, a side effect of the movie industry's relocating much of its production to Canada.

Needing not only to save money, but to earn money, Ms. Gault turned her hobby into a business -- Grocerygame.com -- and built a network of franchisees in 48 states offering subscription advice on grocery savings. She now has 26 employees. Her husband is one of them.

TD 

Women are starting their own businesses at a far higher rate than men, and it follows that many, like Ms. Gault, are hiring their husbands. Couples have worked together since the days of the family farm and the mom-and-pop store. Is the dynamic different when he works for her?

''Oh, yes,'' said Tamara Monosoff, founder of Mom Inventors Inc., which licenses baby products invented by mothers. Her husband, Brad Kofoed, joined the company in July of last year and is now director of sales. ''I couldn't work for him,'' she said, only half-joking. ''If he ran this it would feel like a hierarchy. Women are more collaborative, so it's more of a partnership.''

Ms. Gault acknowledges that ''it was a little bit of an adjustment,'' when she first asked her husband to help out. It was in 2003, when she began franchising and desperately needed a ''girl Friday to sit next to me'' and take care of the details. Mr. Gault took on the role and ''he just worked his tail off,'' his wife said, though he did have a tendency ''to ask me for things he could find himself, like the number of our accountant, because he was used to asking me for things like that at home.'' He did so well that he is now the company's chief financial officer.

Gina Seamans, who founded Accent Public Relations seven years ago and whose husband, Jim, is her vice president for operations, said, ''It took us both a while to get comfortable with me gaining the 'boss' power.'' The only thing they ever argue about as a couple, she says, is the to-do list she gives her husband, um, operations vice president, every week. ''It is a constant issue,'' she said, ''for me to walk the line of seeing it as 'work' rather than a 'honey-do.'''

Carefully delineated job descriptions seem to be crucial in these work-life relationships. Susan Dunk, inventor of the ToddlerCoddler, a device that provides head and neck support for children in car seats, invited her husband, John, to handle accounts payable and shipments when business grew 900 percent last year. ''I told him I was founder and C.E.O. and he would get to be president,'' she said. ''The C.E.O. gets to fire the president.''

Separation of space is another. The Gaults share an office, but have a partition down the middle so they can talk to each other while maintaining separate turf. Sharon DiMinico, who started the franchise company Learning Express in 1995 and relies on her husband, Lou, to oversee the leasing agreements, needs more distance. ''We have a 10,000-square-foot building,'' she said of their headquarters. ''He's upstairs on the extreme right and I'm downstairs on the extreme left. We cross paths at meetings.''

The biggest issue of all, however, seems to be money. Although a few of the women bosses I spoke to earn more than their husbands (''that makes sense to both of us,'' Ms. Dunk said), most avoid the landmine in the most collaborative way.

Ms. Gault said: ''He's the C.F.O., so he decides our salaries. Every time I get a raise, he gets a raise. He will not let me make more. He just gave both of us bonuses and he gave us the same. I said I want one dollar more and he won't give it to me.''

Ms. Seamans goes one step further. Having brought her husband on board to rein in her ''control freak tendencies'' about money, she keeps up on the broad strokes of their finances but remains purposely in the dark about their relative salaries. Every month, Mr. Seamans hands her two paychecks. The first one is hers. ''He gives it to me upside down,'' she said, ''so I can endorse it.'' The second one is his. ''He gives that to me right side up so I can sign it. I always see what he gets paid, but I never see what I get paid. I hope I'm making more than him.''

Drawing (Drawing by Randall Enos)


NS 
csmlbs : Small Business/Entrepreneurs | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfcpex : FC&E Executive News Filter

RE 
usa : United States | namz : North America

PUB 
New York Times Digital (Full Text)

AN 
Document NYTF000020051009e1a9000cd


SE National Desk; SECTA
HD More Help for Businesses
WC 133 words
PD 14 October 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 22
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

In the face of increasing criticism over how little help it has given businesses hurt by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, the Small Business Administration announced yesterday that it was making it easier for business owners to apply for low-interest disaster loans.

Borrowers will no longer have to supply three years' worth of monthly sales analyses and tax returns, and title searches will not be required for loans of less than $50,000.

TD 

The agency has been under fire on Capitol Hill and in Louisiana over the slow pace of business aid. As of yesterday, it had approved only 49 business loans worth $3.4 million, a spokeswoman said.

The agency has approved more than $68 million in loans under a different program that helps homeowners.


IN 
i81501 : Credit Types/Services | ibnk : Banking/Credit

NS 
csmlbs : Small Business/Entrepreneurs | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfcpex : FC&E Executive News Filter

RE 
usa : United States | namz : North America

PUB 
New York Times Digital (Full Text)

AN 
Document NYTF000020051014e1ae00025


CLM HOME FRONT
SE Job Market; SECT10
HD A Sideline Outshines the Main Line
BY By Joseph P. Fried
WC 842 words
PD 30 October 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 1
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

IN their quest for artistic creativity and commercial profitability, cotton is their canvas, and it suits them to a T.

Well, to a T-shirt.

TD 

For the last five years, Rebecca and Paul Steinman have been building a business in Brooklyn producing screen-printed T-shirts -- an enterprise that they started, in part, to supply another company that Mr. Steinman was already operating.

The other company specialized in renting equipment for movie shoots, and Mr. Steinman often had T-shirts made that he handed out to promote that business. He ordered the shirts from companies that embellished items to order.

In 2000, Ms. Steinman said recently, she and her husband decided that they knew enough about screen-printing to produce the shirts themselves. Moreover, she said, they decided to start a business that would screen-print T-shirts for other companies that wanted them for distribution as promotional products, gifts or mementos.

And as part of their new venture, they would also screen-print their own line of designer T-shirts for sale to the public.

''I wanted to satisfy my own creative urge, to put my own work out there,'' said Ms. Steinman, 32, who majored in theater at the University of Michigan with a concentration in costume design. Shortly after they were married in 1999, she began working in her husband's movie equipment rental business, which he had started with a partner in the early 1990's.

She and Mr. Steinman, 35, called their screen-printing business Quist Industries Ltd. -- a name that might not indicate what the company makes but ''stands for quality, utility, innovation, style and technology,'' Ms. Steinman said. In 2001, Quist's first full year of operation, it had $14,000 in sales, she said. By last year, annual sales were up to $90,000, and she estimated that this year they would be more than $120,000.

Despite the rising revenues, though, the business remained in the red until last year, when ''we just about broke even,'' Ms. Steinman said, adding that she expected only a slight profit this year. As with many growing businesses in their early years, the increased revenue has been made possible by increased capital investment and staffing, which, of course, has raised costs.

The Steinmans hired their first full-time Quist employee, a studio assistant, in January 2004, and they currently have two full-time workers, a printer and a saleswoman. They have bought a $40,000 automatic screen-printing press, with a production capacity of several hundred shirts an hour, replacing the hand press that Ms. Steinman said could produce no more than about 100 shirts an hour.

In screen-printing, a stencil of an image is produced on a screen of mesh material -- polyester in Quist's case -- that has been stretched over a frame, and a special ink is applied through the stencil to adorn the fabric. Photo-sensitive emulsions, a light table with a high-intensity light, and a dryer with a conveyor belt are also among the materials and machinery in the company's production line in an old industrial building on the waterfront in Red Hook.

The Steinmans continue to operate the movie equipment rental business, Dragon's Head Productions, at the same location, but they are spending an ever greater portion of their time on Quist. Mr. Steinman said he thought they would phase out Dragon's Head ''somewhere down the road'' to concentrate entirely on the print-screening business.

These days, about 80 percent of Quist's revenue comes from jobs done under contract for other parties, including companies, nonprofit groups and designers who are putting out their own lines of screen-printed merchandise but contracting with companies like Quist to apply the adornments. T-shirts are still two-thirds of Quist's contract jobs, but now the company also embellishes items like tote bags and baseball hats. It also does embroidery.

Ms. Steinman said she hopes to increase her company's own line of designer T-shirts, which are sold in small stores, from 20 percent to 50 percent of revenue. ''We've produced about three dozen designs and are now showing about a dozen,'' she said, pointing to a row of shirts that are part of the company's ''urban wildlife series.''

Among the colorful images is an orange and brown squirrel adorning a gray shirt. (On a pink shirt the squirrel is fuchsia and black.) There is also a pigeon, ''our biggest seller,'' Ms. Steinman said, and a rat, which also does well. And a giant cockroach. ''People love it or can't stand it,'' she said.

Photo: T-SHIRTS MADE TO ORDER -- Rebecca and Paul Steinman of Quist Industries Ltd. with their automatic screen-printing press in Red Hook, Brooklyn. They expect a profit this year. (Photo by Robert Stolarik for The New York Times)


RF 
This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.

IN 
i4756 : Printing | i475 : Printing/Publishing | imed : Media

NS 
csmlbs : Small Business/Entrepreneurs | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfcpex : FC&E Executive News Filter

RE 
namz : North America | usny : New York | usa : United States | use : Northeast U.S.

PUB 
New York Times Digital (Full Text)

AN 
Document NYTF000020051030e1au000aj


CLM UP AND RUNNING
SE Small Business; SECTG
HD Rules and Advice for Turning You Inc. From Idea to Reality
BY By JENNIFER BAYOT
WC 1387 words
PD 16 November 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 2
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

YOU'RE slaving away at your job, and you can tell you're going to finish yet another tedious task on time. Your boss is nice enough. The pay is decent, but you need something more. So amid the buzz of the office environment, you temporarily turn your attention to the Web to order supplies for You Inc., the small business you have quietly started on the side.

Wait a minute. You have crossed the line. According to experts on business ethics, workers aren't supposed to use their employer's resources for their own entrepreneurial endeavors.

TD 

Instead, experts on entrepreneurship say, would-be magnates should focus on their time outside the office, asking questions like, Am I really using my home computer, my Internet connection and my daily commute as efficiently as a business would?

For aspiring entrepreneurs, viewing your life as a business can be critical to preparing for operating a business full time, says Judith Cone, a vice president of the Kauffman Foundation who is in charge of its programs encouraging entrepreneurship. ''If you're going to apply an analytical, strategic approach to your business idea,'' she said, ''it makes a lot of sense to turn the spotlight on you as the vehicle that's going to make this happen.''

With that in mind, small-business owners and advisers suggest a few areas where you may want to make improvements as you contemplate an expansion of You Inc.:

EMBRACE THE ESTABLISHMENT

The government help available to small businesses can often be specific, like a loan program exclusively for export businesses or a federal contract seeking minority-owned businesses, said Ivan Szanto, a retired business executive who mentors aspiring entrepreneurs at the New York City district of Score, a nonprofit group affiliated with the Small Business Administration.

To find all applicable programs would be too time consuming for most business owners -- ''dozens and dozens of programs might apply to this business,'' said Mr. Szanto, assistant district director of Score's New York chapter. Instead, counselors can provide that information free and quickly, he said. ''We used to say it's one of the best-kept secrets'' for entrepreneurs, he said. ''A lot of people don't know that we exist. What we do is give them practical advice.''

Even the counselors are unlikely to find details on government financing to start a business, Mr. Szanto said. ''There is a belief out there that the government gives grants, but that's a terrible misconception,'' he said. ''There are almost no grants from the government to start a business -- but there are loan guarantees.'' With government loan guarantees, entrepreneurs can often borrow more money to start their businesses than lenders would allow otherwise.

Mr. Szanto says that a Score counselor can also advise budding business owners of ethical ways to tap their current employers for help in starting their businesses. He gives the example of a legal secretary who may want to open a side business typing up documents. ''That's fine,'' he said.

He warns, however, that employees must be careful not to exploit their employer's resources for their own business: photocopying materials, making calls on company time and basically using any resource that a boss would be displeased to know about are all unethical.

In addition, most companies have a formal disclosure process when it comes to outside commercial ventures. Follow it to the letter, Mr. Szanto advises; for many people it will mean telling a boss about the business and promising that their job performance won't suffer. They need never mention it again -- unless they have to break the news that they are leaving to run their business.

USE BROADBAND BETTER

While you may be accustomed to multiple phone bills, it should be tougher for You Inc. to dismiss Internet phone service for as little as $10 a month. James E. Gaskin, who profiles broadband phones in ''Talk Is Cheap,'' says that unless you never make long-distance calls and have no extra features on your land line (even call waiting or caller ID), using your existing broadband connection for phone service will inevitably save you money.

Afraid the lines may be unreliable? When Hurricane Katrina left land lines and cellphones useless, Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans used Internet phone service, running eight lines from one account.

Then there are your finances. Sure, the bank is on your way to work, A.T.M.'s are everywhere, and paying your bills by mail takes minutes. But conventional banking and bill paying are time-wasters compared with their online alternatives, as Robert Siciliano, a security consultant, said that he learned after founding IDTheftSecurity.com in 2000. Although he said he preferred back then to pay and receive his own bills by mail, the needs of his clients and vendors pushed him to manage his business accounts and invoices on the Web. ''In the corporate world, you don't want paper, you want things streamlined,'' he said.

He made the switch with his personal finances: he now banks online and receives his phone and cable bills by e-mail. ''I don't deal with paper anymore, and I learned that in business,'' he said, ''because in business, time and efficiency are everything.''

DON'T FORGET TO BARTER

You know about bartering in your personal life, don't you? When you ask friends to cat-sit or help you move, do you usually offer them cash? No, you promise them dinner or homemade cookies.

Yet most small businesses do not swap goods and services. Although the International Reciprocal Trade Association, an industry group, estimates that bartering last year amounted to $4.4 billion in North America, that activity was concentrated in fewer than 1 percent of businesses.

Krista Vardabash, the association's executive director, says that many business owners mistakenly think that bartering occurs under the table and requires one-on-one exchanges.

''Because it's just a different concept, they almost automatically assume that it can't be legit,'' she said. There is misinformation about it.

A more familiar form of bartering is offering a small stake in your business in exchange for any number of services. To build up what is now Homestead Technologies -- a Menlo Park, Calif., company whose do-it-yourself Web sites have attracted 12 million registered users -- the founder, Justin S. Kitch, swapped shares in the company for legal services, reduced rent and even discounted lines of credit.

When starting out, ''all you really have to offer is your energy and passion and expertise,'' Mr. Kitch said, ''and there are a lot of people willing to work with you in some way or another.''

Hundreds of barter exchanges operate nationwide, allowing far more trades and much more flexibility. Rather than having to swap directly for what you want, you can offer your services and earn ''trade credits'' through the exchange.

Though no money changes hands, such trades are still treated as cash transactions for tax purposes.

DELEGATE

Your ability to outsource and delegate, including at home, can make or break your blossoming business, experts say. As sole proprietor of You Inc., you could pool your efforts with other businesses, says Frances McGuckin, a small-business adviser and author of books on entrepreneurship. You can also outsource tasks to technology or appliances -- have bills paid automatically online, buy tax-preparation software or let a digital video recorder like TiVo remember to save your favorite shows.

Such delegating is also good business training, helping you to rely on a network of vendors, bankers and others. It not only frees up your time but also keeps you from making costly mistakes, particularly on tax forms and other legal documents.

Your most important allies will be a smart lawyer and a deft accountant, says John Thaler, a specialist in small-business law and the owner of an independent record company in Studio City, Calif. ''My lawyer friends and I have a saying, It doesn't take 100 clients to build a successful law practice; it takes five who never listen,'' Mr. Thaler writes in ''The Elements of Small Business.'' ''Don't be one of those five.''

Drawings (Illustrations by John Ueland)

CLM UP AND RUNNING
SE Small Business; SECTG
HD In New Orleans, the Wait for Federal Loans Drags On
BY By ELIZABETH OLSON
WC 944 words
PD 16 November 2005
SN The New York Times
SC NYTF
ED Late Edition - Final
PG 2
LA English
CY Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

WASHINGTON -- AT a Senate hearing last week, Walter Isaacson, the former CNN chief who is vice chairman of the agency leading Louisiana's recovery from Hurricane Katrina, identified the state's two highest priorities: stronger levees and loans to help the 80,000 or so small businesses in the hardest-hit areas stay afloat.

But as of yesterday, the Small Business Administration said that it had approved only 1,078 loans to small businesses for property damage or economic losses across the Gulf Coast from Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, while denying 1,945 applications. According to the agency, 24,268 business-related loan applications were still being processed.

TD 

Anger at the slow pace spilled over at the hearing last week, before the Senate Small Business and Entrepreneurship Committee.

Mr. Isaacson said that in the hard-hit areas of Louisiana, as of Nov. 3 only 276 business loans had been approved, a pace he called ''devastating, '' while rejections were ''alarmingly high.''

Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, a committee member, complained that ''Our businesses were wiped out by a wall of water, while S.B.A. help is coming in at a trickle.'' The committee's Republican chairwoman, Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, said she had ''growing doubts about the agency's management and leadership.''

Hector V. Barreto, the agency's administrator, insisted that the disaster ''is 10 times larger than any disaster we've had before.'' Because the agency handles loan requests after disasters from homeowners as well as businesses, it has been swamped by more than 200,000 homeowner applications. The agency has quadrupled its work force, to nearly 4,100.

Mr. Barreto told Congress that the agency received 55 percent of the applications in the last two weeks of October and first week of November, giving the short-staffed S.B.A. little time to sift through them.

Even so, the agency had processed only 17 percent of the loan applications filed, say Senate committee figures, and has a backlog that will take at least four months to get through at its current pace.

Senator Snowe said the agency dragged its feet when it should have recruited more loan officers immediately.

And the S.B.A. may well receive nearly twice as many applications as have been filed so far, committee members warned.

The lagging loans are just one more aspect to an already grim situation, state officials contend. ''The situation is not good here,'' said Mary Lynn Wilkerson, director of the Louisiana Small Business Development Center. ''Clearly the loans are not coming quickly enough, and we have lost 40 percent of our small businesses so far.''

Take Don Johnsen, who owns Royal Crown Coffee Service Inc., which provides machines and supplies for coffee and tea to restaurants, schools and businesses in New Orleans and Slidell, La. He had no insurance, and he says he needs $70,000 from the agency to tide him over until he can rebuild his business.

''I applied about six weeks ago,'' he said, ''but I have not had any contact since then, not a phone call or even a letter of receipt. This can't go on too much longer since I can't even pay myself.''

The agency says it is simplifying its loan requirements, and announced last week a pilot program called GO Loans, which allows a small business to borrow up to $150,000 from a commercial bank within 24 hours after its application. The loans, available through next September, are 85 percent guaranteed by the federal government; interest rates are set by the banks.

This contrasts with S.B.A. disaster loans, which have a low 4 percent rate, and pits the program against legislation, introduced by a bipartisan group of lawmakers, to authorize money for bridge loans to carry small-business owners over the lengthy agency approval process. Senator Snowe and some of her colleagues blamed the Bush administration for derailing the $450 million assistance package on bridge loans, which passed the Senate unanimously, by allowing it to be cut recently from the final legislation.

While it was awaiting federal aid, Louisiana started its own bridge-loan program for small businesses, said Donald M. Pierson, assistant secretary of Louisiana Economic Development. ''We've exhausted the $10 million in funding,'' he said, ''and we've only scratched the surface. We could have used $150 million to $200 million.''

Concern over the lumbering pace of loan approval and the high rejection rate, legislators, including Representative Nydia M. Velazquez of New York, the ranking Democrat on the House Committee on Small Business, have asked for the Government Accountability Office to investigate.

Earlier budget cutbacks led to eliminating some S.B.A. offices and consolidating others this year. Congressional critics think this set the stage for an inadequate response after Katrina. Another major complaint has been the agency's new computer system, which requires scanning all applications submitted on paper.

An agency spokesman, Dennis Byrne, responded that the unprecedented number of applications had created ''capacity concerns.'' He said 5,000 applications were being entered into the computer system each day.

It may be too late for many owners. Mr. Johnsen, the operator of the coffee service, said he might close his business and walk away after 20 years.

''I figure that if by the end of December, I don't have the loan,'' he said, ''I will have to close up.''

Photo: WILL WORK -- Intersections in New Orleans are plastered with signs posted by businesses offering postflood services. (Photo by Alex Brandon/Associated Press)
